text: [Music]
hi everyone and welcome to my talk on machine learning on the edge i'm kathryn drammell i'm really excited to be here
at qcon live and thanks to sergey for inviting me to be a part of this track and i'm really excited to talk about
advances in federated learning at the edge with you today so when i think about the edge i often
think about small embedded devices iot other types of things that might have a
small computer in them and i might not even realize that and so i recently learned that these
little scooters that are all over my city in berlin germany and maybe even yours as well
that they are collecting quite a lot of data and sending it and so when i think about the data they
might be collecting when i put on my data science and machine learning hat and i think about the problems that they
might want to solve they might want to know about maintenance they might want to know about road and weather conditions they might want to know about
driver performance and really the ultimate question they're trying to answer is this last one which
is is this gonna result in some sort of problem for the scooter or for the human
or for the other things around the scooter and the human and so um these are the types of questions we
ask when we think about data and machine learning and when we think about it on the edge or with embedded small systems this
often becomes a problem because traditional machine learning needs quite a lot of extra information to answer
these questions and so let's take a look at a traditional machine learning system and investigate how it might go about
collecting this data and answering this question well first all the data would have to be aggregated and collected into a data
lake it might need to be standardized or munged or cleaned or something done with it beforehand
then eventually the data is pulled usually by a data science team or by scripts written by data engineering or
data scientists on the team that data is transformed so initially we might do eda
or what's called exploratory data analysis then we might decide okay here's the data how i want it prepared
and then we might automate it with a pipeline and then eventually that goes into model
training testing validation and selection and so in that case um what
it's trying to do what we're trying to do as a data team is figure out what's the best way to solve this problem with
the machine learning that we have available and the data that we have available eventually that's an iterative process
and so we might decide at the end is we have one or two models that we'd like to try and we're ready to deploy them or
one or more of them and so at that point in time we would deploy them uh usually to a cloud service or other api that is
reachable for the participants or for whatever system's going to use the machine learning um this could also be
internal so it could be something that's only reachable or internal to
let's say the scooter the you know scooter centralized um that interacts
via another api with the scooters themselves and we can immediately hopefully start
to see some of the limitations of this first off that we need the data collected so this all has to happen some
which way and be sent over the network i'm not sure what type of network connection scooters have but probably
it's not stable probably it doesn't have a huge up power and so for this reason
uh this is going to be a problem then we have to collect it all across the data lake so then we need to
aggregate across many different locations then we're going to train the model and so on so when we think about things like mobile devices
small embedded systems robots in factories we can see that some of the
problems here not only from a connectivity point of view but also from a memory storage compute power and then
also aggregating and sending all of that and then having them interact in real time with an api to make a decision
that's a lot that's a lot of problems and limitations that we can immediately see
and so how do we approach these well one such approach is to use federated
learning and so federated learning was presented by google and was actively
used in production i believe first by google when they wanted to learn on android devices and so there was
numerous problems that they wanted to solve on android devices let's take an easy example of predictive
keyboard support so i want to build a better predictive text model for spanish speakers by using keyboard
data what i will do is i'll first have the model that i'm actively using that's the
that's the blue circle i will send it out to all of the android devices now
there's some selection criteria here so first off i i only want spanish uh
language keyboards so that's gonna rule out some others and then i want the process to complete successfully so that
means that i want devices that have high battery power or that are charging i
want devices with a good or stable mobile or internet connection
and perhaps i want somebody with enough text that i can help learn so perhaps there's multiple criteria there that are
selected at that point in time the model is sent to those phones then the machine learning happens on the
device so now the device is essentially doing some of the training for me
and that can be an iterative process or a one-shot process but at that point in time then there is
an update at the end of that and that update is not the data itself but instead a representation usually in some
sort of vectorized form that tells me okay this is the direction that the
machine learning model should go to improve for based on the data on this device
and so all of those updates across all of those different devices are collected and they're usually aggregated so this
is step b and sent to a centralized aggregator which then uses some sort of computation to combine
them so this can be averaging sums some other computation depending on the algorithm and
the architecture of the model and then that is sent back out to all the devices so then every device has an
updated model i myself as the person managing the process i also have an updated model
and presumably then another round could start or we could say okay now the model is good enough we stop here
so when we think about the architecture the design that i just showed you is the classic one where we have one
centralized aggregator with distributed participants however you can also imagine other architectures such as
clustering participants together and deploying multiple aggregators depending
on your infrastructure this might be a better approach or a worse approach and so this is
something that should be discussed between the data science teams and machine learning teams as well as your
infrastructure teams and obviously i think that this is a good group to help solve those problems let's think about
exactly how should this be deployed and finally we can also think of a scenario where it's fully distributed and this is
where we start entering the cryptography realm and we can think about things like a multi-party computation or other forms
of distributed encrypted computations that allow multiple participants to
again do the machine learning on their local devices and then to coordinate with one another to combine those
updates and then to send the result out in a meaningful manner and so if you have exposure to the
cryptographic protocols and communities around things like a multi-party computation and other types of
multi-party approaches then this might be an interesting way to think about the problem of course this also adds massive
amounts of complexity for coordinating all the different devices
so it helps to look at a practical use case we're going to look at phlox today which is federated learning of cohorts
that's also from google and so this federated learning of cohorts was a proposal
and i think it's active on some chrome browsers already but it's essentially a proposal to say
let's do away with third party cookies because they're awful and nobody likes them
they they are a privacy nightmare and many different browsers are you know
removing functionality for third-party cookies or automatically blocking third-party cookies right so
let's do away with third-party cookies but what should we use in order to do targeted personalized advertising if we
don't have third-party cookies and that's what google proposed flocks will do so their idea for flocks is that you get
assigned a cohort based on maybe something you like or different browsing preferences browsing history and so on
so here we have a plum group and we have an orange group and we have these two different cohorts and perhaps if you
were a fruit seller you might say hey yeah i want to target this plum cohort
with plum ads and this orange cohort with orange ads for example
let's take a look at how it works and what's the federated learning part of it well the first thing that happens is
when you open up a flock enabled chrome browser is you get assigned a cohort if you don't already have one
this is probably an iterative process those details weren't shared but it's probably an iterative process so it's
likely that my cohort will change over time because obviously my interests and my
browsing changes over time and so as i i start browsing as a cohort and let's say
i'm now in the plum cohort and it turns out via federated learning that we find that you know five different users
visited plums.com today then that small piece of information could be sent as an
update to the aggregator which could then update the targeted ad model and
the process continues as you can see this is not a typical federated learning because the ad targeting model is likely
not going to be shipped out and running on all of our devices but this is kind of a hybrid model where
there's some parts centralized in some parts federated the cohort model most likely is shipped
out and so that is also something that will probably be iterated across cohorts over
time and sent and updated and so we can see how this process works and
the goal again was to resolve the privacy problems and just the poor user experience as well
of online targeted ads where sometimes you would click on something that would follow you for days um
and so we can ask will this work does this address those problems and um probably
it will probably lead to better ads because it's again an iterative process and so you're not forever in a bucket
based on something that you liked you know five five weeks ago so that that most likely from a data perspective will
change however from a privacy perspective does it guarantee us something um is is my membership in
plums plums lovers uh private to me or can this be public in some way so this
this is a kind of higher level philosophical question which we won't have time to answer today
but it's interesting to think about um what are the qualities that uh you would
want or be comfortable with being aggregated for your cohorts and google already said that medical history and sexual
preferences would not be included but are those the only categories in addition electronic frontier
foundation as well as several other prominent technologists came out and critiqued the flock approach because
it's fairly easy to discern potential privacy attacks such as someone using flock
arrives on my website and i present them with a login screen and now i have both their cohort and
their login or i use browser fingerprinting now i have their browser fingerprint and their cohort and these
combined um again when we think of cohorts as a few thousand people um create an environment where it might
be fairly easy to de-identify or sorry de-anonymize or re-identify
those individuals and so when we think about collecting a massive
database let's say we had large presence or we aggregated across many different partners or other properties we could
potentially create a database full of user ids and their cohorts full of
browser fingerprints and their cohorts full of a combination of those which might even allow us to reverse engineer
cohort selection as well as potentially to reverse engineer even uh who those
individuals are from the cohorts so it's not a silver bullet for privacy
so let's think about the benefits and weaknesses of federated learning one big
benefit is that there's no centralized data collection so i don't have to send and centralize the data all in one place
instead the data remains on the device and i can use federated learning to get
small updates to send to again to the aggregators a weakness of this is that the data must
be standardized on the device so remember when we had traditional machine learning we had a large pipeline we
could change and and clean and segregate data in different ways
when it's on the device it needs to be ready for machine learning or it needs to be quickly ready for machine learning
and so this is great if you've already standardized data on your devices but maybe it would be hard if you haven't
thought about that problem yet second huge benefit is more diverse data
sets and so we have way more diverse data when we think about expanding our reach
to many many different edge devices that's one of the reasons why google even thought about federated learning is
how do we get better targeted improvements for particular types of machine learning that we're trying to do
but when you get that more diverse data from more varied users or population you
also have to think of the fact that it's unevenly distributed and so when we look at the example of
our scooters if i'm riding a scooter in berlin and you're riding a scooter in a
very very different uh city in wait the way that commute works
then your my updates might actually cancel each other out so it would depend on the data science team
also thinking it through obviously with other teams of what's the goal of this model and are we going to be able to
sub-select populations that allow us to diversify our data without um creating a bias in
and of itself because of the unevenly distributed data that's available
finally huge benefit that i think is under undervalued benefit of federated
learning is on-device machine learning so how do we make real-time decisions um
we can also even personalize the model on the device in in certain ways when we
think about uh federated learning that allows for particularly smaller updates to smaller
groups and so this on-device machine learning the speed
and the ability for us to to answer those questions on the device is huge
a weakness of it if if it wasn't already clear to you is that all of those devices must have the model or have
whatever models they are working on and so if there's proprietary or
confidential information let's say in the model then one should think about the
appropriate security concerns there finally privacy is often touted as a
benefit of federated learning and i i'm not here to say that it isn't it definitely is
it's better to send a small update than it is to send let's say the entire browsing history or something like this
to a centralized location however those small updates can leak information
and there's several other types of privacy attacks like the one that we just talked about for flocks and so the
the benefits of the privacy and the guarantees of the privacy are very
dependent on the implementation and if you're really choosing federated learning for privacy benefits then you
should think about also employing techniques such as secure computation of
of the aggregates or also adding differential privacy gradient clipping
any other types of techniques that are common in terms of thinking
about the privacy of those updates and and what guarantees you'd like to have
in the system that you're designing so when does it make sense to do machine
learning in a federated way well my first question to you is if traditional machine learning works then you should
probably use it so federated learning is super cool but it's also still super new
and so if you're looking for a tried and true and 100 guaranteed solution it's
probably not it unless you're working at google or one of the other places that has been
running federated learning for a long time but maybe traditional machine learning
doesn't work and you're excited to think about federated learning so my second question for you would be is your data
standardized and can the devices run federated learning software and so i have a list at the end of this talk of a
bunch of different open source libraries to play around with and get a feel for
federated learning software i hope you find one you like that you can try out i'd be very excited to hear your
feedback and experience um but so can the devices run them
run that software and is the data standardized if not i would recommend that you try distributed data analysis
first which is essentially trying to ask questions or query the data on the devices and then sending just the
aggregate summations or counts or things like this back to a central location and then have
your data team or if you're a data person yourself take a look at it and start answering the
questions and eventually hopefully you can roll out a fully federated system
but if the data is standardized and the devices can run the software then the final decision for you to make is how
you want to do aggregations do you want to do them centralized or clustered i would recommend centralize is going to
have less complexity and be simpler to start with but if you already have a clustered setup or if your system is
already designed in that manner maybe clustered is easier for you to go to so that's kind of
up to you how how you want to structure that and what questions and requirements you have
to make that final decision some other factors to consider are the privacy requirements and guarantees
which again are not automatically built in and are something that you have to think about so please talk with privacy
and security experts on your team i'm also a privacy and security expert so should you ever want to reach out
please let me know and then there's also connectivity requirements so what are you going to do
when the device is lost is there a certain tipping point when a particular amount of
devices are lost where you want to actually halt the round and stop uh stop the process so these are questions that
you have to think about and should think about again combining the knowledge from your software and infrastructure teams
with the knowledge from your data team and finally i strongly believe that the
future of machine learning and data science and analytics is distributed and so when we think about the problems
that we face as as humans as parts of our many societies and our one world
we can think about many situations where if we had intelligent
edge devices we could probably help minimally help nudge things in positive
directions and so when we think about farming and you know climate related changes to
farming and the need for food in in our growing world when we think about coronavirus and
other types of viruses and how how we can track let's say their progress
across across the globe when we think about climate-related natural disasters such as flooding hurricanes and so on
and so forth when you think about all of these things we can also think about end devices that would be appropriately
positioned to ask and answer questions and potentially to help create earlier
warning systems to help create better preparation again for
folks in our governments folks that are working in ngos folks that are trying to solve these
problems and instead again of going and trust trying to collect all data possible and then we'll figure it out
later we're thinking about the problem and actively asking what data do we need to
solve this problem and how do we go get it and i think that's honestly a much more intelligent and also much more
privacy aware way to solve these problems is what problem am i trying to solve how
can i use edge devices to help me along this way and is this a good thing to to do
distributed data analysis or data science as well as potentially federated learning for can i solve this problem
this way rather than randomly collecting data and hoping we get to the outcomes so i hope you'll give federated learning
or start thinking about how to distribute your data science and collectivize it and answer ask and
answer the right questions and ensure you're collecting the right data from the right
places if you have questions i'm really excited to go through them with you today i'm
also excited to hear use cases or other ideas that you have if you ever want to reach out here's my contact information
but i'm really looking forward to continuing the conversation in a moment and hearing all of your ideas thoughts
and questions thank you so much for your time
